column1: the:  I just bought a new shirt and some new shoes. The shirt was pretty expensive, but the shoes weren't.

column2: used to say that the particular person or thing being mentioned is the best, most famous, etc. In this use, "the" is usually given strong pronunciation:

column2: used to say that the particular person or thing being mentioned is the best, most famous, etc. In this use, "the" is usually given strong pronunciation:

column2: With certain verbs, "and" can mean "in order to":

column2: If "and" is used to join two words that are the same, it makes their meaning stronger:

column2: If you say that you have done with something or someone, or have done performing a particular action, you mean that you have finished what you were doing with something or someone, or what you were saying to someone, or that you have finished the action:

column2: If you say there is or that you have no time to lose, it means that you must do quickly whatever it is that you want to do:

column1: time:  Do you have time for a quick drink after work?
column2: If you have time, you have enough time to do something:

column1: time:  I'd like to learn to sail, but I don't have the time (= I am too busy).

column2: a period of time added to the end of a football match because play was stopped during the game, usually to take care of players who were hurt:

column1: time:  After a time, it became clear that nobody was interested in coming to the meetings.

column2: used to show that something is limited to not more than, or is not anything other than, the people, things, amount, or activity stated:

column2: used to show that something is limited to not more than, or is not anything other than, the people, things, amount, or activity stated:

column1: only:  It's only natural that you should worry about your children.
column2: used to show that something is limited to not more than, or is not anything other than, the people, things, amount, or activity stated:

column2: used when saying that something unpleasant will happen as a result of an action or a failure to act:

column1: only:  I'd love to go to Australia. I only wish I could afford to.
column2: used to show that you feel sorry about something that cannot happen when explaining why it cannot happen:

column2: used to emphasize what you are hoping or wishing for:

column2: used to emphasize what you are hoping or wishing for:

column1: only:  She's only locked herself out of her flat again!
column2: used to show that you think someone has done something silly:

column2: used to refer to something that happens almost immediately after something else:

column1: only:  We'd only just set off when the car broke down.
column2: used to refer to something that happens almost immediately after something else:

column1: only:  There was only just enough food to go round.
column2: almost not:

column1: only:  We got there in time for our flight, but only just (= but we almost did not).
column2: almost not:

column1: only:  Not only did he turn up late, he also forgot his books.
column2: used to say that two related things are true or happened, especially when this is surprising or shocking:

column1: only:  If this project fails, it will affect not only our department, but also the whole organization.
column2: used to say that two related things are true or happened, especially when this is surprising or shocking:

column1: only:  If you want any help, you have only to ask.
column2: If you say you have only (got) to do something, you mean that it is all you need to do in order to achieve something else:

column1: only:  You only have to look at her face to see that she's not well.
column2: If you say you have only (got) to do something, you mean that it is all you need to do in order to achieve something else:

column1: only:  I'd invite Frances to the party, only (= but I will not because) I don't want her husband to come.
column2: used to show what is the single or main reason why something mentioned in the first part of the sentence cannot be performed or is not completely true:

column2: used to show what is the single or main reason why something mentioned in the first part of the sentence cannot be performed or is not completely true:

column1: so:  The word itself is so rare as to be almost obsolete.
column2: very, extremely, or to such a degree:

column1: so:  Don't wear that - it's so last year (= it was fashionable last year but not now).

column2: used before a noun or before "not" to emphasize what is being said:

column2: used usually before the verbs "have", "be", or "do", and other auxiliary verbs to express the meaning "in the same way" or "in a similar way":

column2: used instead of repeating an adjective that has already been mentioned:

column2: used when you are representing the size of something:

column1: right:  You have every right (= you have a good reason) to complain.
column2: the fact that a person or animal can expect to be treated in a fair, morally acceptable, or legal way, or to have the things that are necessary for life:

column1: right:  I think I'm quite within my rights to demand a full refund.
column2: If you are within your rights to do something, you are legally allowed to do it:

column1: right:  He has acquired the film rights to the book (= he is allowed to make a film of the book).
column2: legal controls over who is allowed to use a book or film:

column1: right:  The company made a rights issue of one new share for every four held.
column2: new shares in a particular company that have become available for people to buy who already own shares:

column1: right:  The company needs over a million dollars to set its finances to rights.
column2: to improve or correct something:

column1: right:  So there I was right, middle of the night, right, and this guy came up to me...
column2: said between parts of a story that you are telling, in order to make certain that people are paying attention and understanding:

column1: right:  It's a terrible situation and we should right it as soon as possible.
column2: If you right a situation or a mistake, you make it better or correct it:

column1: right:  The canoe will right itself if it capsizes.
column2: If a boat rights itself, it turns itself back to its correct position in the water:

column1: type:  There were so many different types of bread that I didn't know which to buy.

column2: If you take someone or something to be something, or if you take someone or something for something, you accept or believe that they are that thing:

column1: take:  I could have taken him for (= believed that he was) your brother.
column2: If you take someone or something to be something, or if you take someone or something for something, you accept or believe that they are that thing:

column1: take:  I'm not going to forge his signature for you! What do you take me for? (= You should not believe I could do a thing like that.)
